==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|な|ら|yomi=on}}

===Etymology===
According to the ancient Japanese book ''Nihon Shoki'', the name "[[Nara]]" derived from the Japanese verb {{m|ja|平す||to flatten|tr=narasu}}<ref>In September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "then, leading selected soldiers, (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of [[Heijō-kyō]]) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama."</ref>. Kunio Yanagida stated, in "The Study of Place Names", Nara stands for flatland.<ref>[http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1879894/118 柳田国男 YANAGIDA Kunio (1936), 『地名の研究』 ''(The Study of Place Names)'', 古今書院, pp.217-219]</ref>.
